## 6.1. False Positives / Negatives {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__false_positives_negatives}
When a security solution detects a threat, but no threat exists, that is a *false positive*. Depending on the complexity

of the solution it may utilize a set of rules, indicators of compromise, or possibly even artificial intelligence to

trigger its warning system. In the case of a solution that creates a lot of false positives, it can be tiring for a team

to go through each alert. Eventually teams are conditioned to ignore the alerts, making the security solution useless.

The key to lowering the false positive rate of a system is to better tune the rule set used to trigger the warnings. A

security team may spend time determining a baseline of events and looking for abnormalities that correspond to actual

attacks. This information can then be used to build a better detection system.

::::: example

::: example-title

Webroot Antivirus

:::

::: example-content

[In 2017 a popular antivirus service created a bad rule that identified certain Windows operating system files as

threats.](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/popular-antivirus-program-mistakenly-ids-windows-threat-creating-chaos-n750521){.link}

The antivirus solution quarantined these files, which were critical for the operation of the machine. The result was a

machine that was unusable.

For 13 minutes, Webroot distributed this rule to its antivirus software shutting down operations on an untold number of

machines. Fortunately Webroot was able to quickly identify the problem and send out an update which would have allowed

the machines to automatically fix the problem. Unfortunately their infrastructure for distributing the update quickly

became overloaded.

:::

:::::

When a security solution fails to identify a threat, this is known as a *false negative*. While no solution can ever be

100% effective, false negatives can undermine confidence in a product. False negatives may be resolved by a skilled SOC

team, closely monitoring what is happening. It is also possible to address false negatives through *Layered Security* a

concept that we will cover next.

::::::

### 3.3.3. Spyware {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__spyware} Malware specifically designed for espionage/data theft is known as spyware. Like ransomware, spyware can also have a monetary payoff for the threat actor. Actors may use extortion to demand payment or the data will be *leaked*. APTs may use spyware as well to obtain secrets of national importance. Customer data, trade secrets, proprietary data, and government secrets are all targets of spyware. Even outside of governments systems, in the corporate setting, spyware is still a major threat.
## Fileless Malware ::: content Malware is often detected by scanning storage for files that match a particular hash or by looking in files to see if they contain patterns. Both of these detection techniques rely on the malware being stored in a file. Fileless malware attempts to avoid detection by leaving no footprint in the file system. This type of malware uses legitimate processes to load itself into memory, often with a registry key created to reload every time the machine is restarted. This creates a persistent, hard-to-detect type of malware that is often used by sophisticated threat actors such as APTs and criminal groups. :::

## Remote Shells
::: content

As you have hopefully experienced by completing the labs, Linux systems traditionally have a powerful shell system that

uses text commands to control the OS. Through the shell you can create, read, update, or delete files, make network

connections, configure kernel parameters, install packages, etc. In fact, all modern operating systems have shells that

can be used to control them. On a Windows machine, having access to PowerShell running as an Administrator is all an

attacker would need to have complete control over the system. Often the outcome of an attack is being able to interact

with a shell remotely on the exploited machine.

In this scenario we say the victim is running a *remote shell*. Remote shells can run in the background on a victim

machine listening on a port for an attacker to connect, but often the exploited machine may not actually have an

external IP the attacker can use to connect. In these instances a *reverse shell* is used. A reverse shell reaches out

from the victim to the attacker and establishes a connection *from the inside*. This is more compatible with the

firewalls/NAT routers that sit between most devices and the Internet.

In either case having privileged shell access to a machine over a remote connection allows an attacker to basically do

anything they want. To that end, many tools have sprung up to provide remote shell access. A machine may already have a

remote shell tool installed, such as an SSH server. Barring that [Netcat](https://netcat.sourceforge.net/){.link} can be

used with any executable to provide access to it over a network. [metasploit](https://www.metasploit.com/){.link} (a

very popular pentesting framework) comes with many payloads, most of which are shells of various types. Programs also

exist to run shells over ICMP, Discord, IRC, or even DNS!

:::

</aside>

## Case Study: Equifax
::: content

[In September of 2017, Equifax announced a data breach the exposed the personal information of 147 million

people.](https://www.ftc.gov/enforcement/cases-proceedings/refunds/equifax-data-breach-settlement){.link} The original

attack made use of an exploit in an outdated version of [Apache Struts](https://struts.apache.org/){.link} which was

being used as part of Equifax's system for handling credit disputes from customers. Once the attackers had gained access

to internal Equifax servers, the began gathering as much information as they could from internal databases.

What is particularly egregious about this data breach is that passwords in many databases were stored in plaintext. This

means that the attackers were able to try the passwords and usernames on other services. While it is important that

users use different passwords for different services it is far more disturbing that a company as large as Equifax did

not have the policies in place to use cryptography to mitigate the risks from such an enormous breach.

:::

## Case Study: Exploiting Non-Rolling Codes
::: content

The importance of non-repeating codes, such as the counter codes used in the CTR and GCM block cipher modes of operation

can be highlighted through analysis of another important technology that uses codes: keyless entry systems. When garage

door openers first came on to the market, the remote would broadcast a single code that the receiver was programmed to

recognize as correct. This meant that anyone listening in could easily get the code and replay the code to open the

garage door with their own device.^\[[^2]\]^ To combat this, companies began using [rolling

codes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rolling_code){.link} in their remotes and receivers. Given the same seed a rolling

code allows each device to generate a sequence of codes that are exactly the same. The remote will use the next code in

a sequence every time the button is hit. The receiver will validate the recieved code if it matches any of the next

several codes in the sequence (in case the button was hit a few times out of range). This effectively mitigates the

replay attack.

Given that this was implemented in the 1980s with garage door remotes, you would assume car manufacturers employ the

same technology in their remotes. In a case of \"everything old is new again\" this isn't true. [Blake Berry

(HackingIntoYourHeart) discovered that several makes and models of cars are actually still vulnerable to a replay

attack.](https://github.com/HackingIntoYourHeart/Unoriginal-Rice-Patty/blob/main/README.md){.link}

Sammy Kamkar also discovered a vulnerablility for rolling codes, named RollJam, which he demonstrated at DEF CON 23.

Kamkar's device jams signals sent by a keyfob, while recording the codes being sent. Once it has two codes recorded,

presumably from the victim pressing the button multiple times, it stops jamming, sends out the first code to unlock the

car and stores the second code to unlock the car at a later time.

:::

</aside>

### 4.4.10. DNSSEC {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__dnssec}
Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC) is a suite of extension specifications designed to authenticate

responses to domain name lookups. This can help prevent MitM attacks by checking the digital signature of the responding

server. While this is certainly helpful, it is important to note that DNSSEC does not provide confidentiality. DNS

resolutions can still be monitored by anyone who has access to the traffic.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.11. IMAP/POP3"}


### 4.4.11. IMAP/POP3 {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__imappop3}
Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) and Post Office Protocol 3 (POP3) are two protocols used to retrieve email from

a server. IMAP is the more recent protocol which supports saving mail on the sever and folders. POP3 is more primitive,

supporting only the retrieval (and subsequent deletion from the server) of emails. Both protocols use cleartext and are

now commonly run over TLS. POP3 defaults to TCP port 110 or 995 if using TLS. IMAP defaults to TCP port 143 or 993 if

using TLS. In the age of webmail it is easy to forget about these protocols, but a security specialist must keep them in

mind as they may still be used in support of corporate devices.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.12. SMTP"}

context: ### 5.5.3. SSRF {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ssrf} Web systems often communicate with internal servers the retrieve information. These may be API servers, databases, or messaging servers. If an attacker can fool a web server into passing a malicious request to its internal server, the attacker and abuse the internal trust of the system. This is referred to a server-side request forgery (SSRF). Once again, this kind of attack is mitigated with input validation, which needs to be included in the application. ::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="5.5.4. Session Hijacking"} ### 5.5.4. Session Hijacking {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__session_hijacking} Session hijacking may involve other methods of compromise, but the end goal is to \"steal\" a session between the victim and another server. Imagine the following scenario: A person logs in to their personal banking website, which issues them a cookie which proves they are authenticated. A bad actor is monitoring the connections through an XSS exploit that forwards all connection cookies to them. The bad actor uses the cookie that was issued to make a transfer from the user's bank account to the bad actors bank account. Depending on the method used, session hijacking may be prevented through use of a better session key or by requiring transport layer security (TLS) to connect. In the above scenario the only way to prevent session hijacking would be to repair the initial XSS vulnerability. ::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="5.5.5. SQL Injection"}

## Golden Ticket
::: content

A dangerous attack against Kerberos authentication exists and goes by the name *Golden Ticket*. TGTs are the cornerstone

of Kerberos security and the Golden Ticket exploit targets them specifically.

Using the fully qualified domain name, security identifier, username of an account, and a KRBTGT password hash an

attacker can create their own TGTs that will grant access to services. The KRBTGT account is an account that Windows

machines use to perform Kerberos administrative tasks. The KRBTGT password hash can be obtained from any machine where

that account was used if the attacker has complete access to the files on the hard drive. This may be done with physical

access or through the use of malware on a victim machine.

An attacker will only be able to forge TGTs until the KRBTGT account password is changed, [so a common remediation

strategy is to change the

password](https://blog.quest.com/what-is-krbtgt-and-why-should-you-change-the-password/){.link}. Ultimately the

administrator will need to determine how the KRBTGT password hash was obtained in the first place.

:::

</aside>

explanation: The primary limitation is that it only prevents further unauthorized access until the attacker obtains the new KRBTGT password hash, highlighting the need for ongoing security measures.

### 9.4.3. Isolation and Containment {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__isolation_and_containment}
The first step in reaction to an incident is to remove the asset from the network so that the damage does not spread. It

is standard procedure for malware to attempt to spread to other machines and the fastest way for it to do that is

through an internal network. By isolating the infected asset, we can help prevent this.

There are a few other tools for containing malware such as sandboxing and snapshots. Sandboxing refers to the practice

of running processes in a controlled environment on a machine. Most web browsers sandbox the JavaScript they run,

meaning that if a website is serving malicious JS it should not be able to affect anything else on the machine.

Snapshots refer to periodically saving the state of the storage device on a machine. This allows the SOC to roll the

machine back to a previous state, before malware was active.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="9.4.4. Recovery"}


### 9.4.4. Recovery {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__recovery}
Recovery can be a long process, but it is the core of responding to an incident. If it is possible to remove malware

from a machine, that action is taken in this step. Breached accounts are also disabled.

Unfortunately it may be impossible to roll back some assets to a previously uncompromised state, in which case they may

need to be restored from a backup or failing that rebuilt from the ground up. Backups make recovery much simpler and

companies that do not have a backup plan typically implement them after their first incident. That being said, malware

may have also found its way into the backups if given enough time on the system. In that case the asset is typically

destroyed and a new one is built. While this can take a long time, it is one of the few ways to know for sure that the

asset isn't compromised.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="9.4.5. Remediation"}
topic: The significance of having a backup plan in place to facilitate recovery and the potential consequences for companies that do not have such a plan.
question: What critical operational and financial risks do organizations incur by not prioritizing comprehensive backup plans as part of their cybersecurity strategy?
answer: Prolonged downtime and substantial financial losses.
explanation: The absence of a robust backup plan exposes organizations to significant risks, including prolonged downtime, substantial financial losses, and potential legal or regulatory repercussions, particularly in the event of a security incident where data or systems are compromised.

topic: Explain how redundancy can be used as a strategy to support business continuity and disaster recovery, and provide examples of how redundancy can be implemented in computer systems.
question: How can redundancy in computer systems be strategically designed to support business continuity and disaster recovery, considering factors such as system criticality, recovery time objectives, and resource availability?
answer: By duplicating critical systems or components and ensuring their proper testing and maintenance to minimize recovery time and support uninterrupted business operations.
explanation: This question requires the application of knowledge about business continuity planning, disaster recovery, and system design to understand how redundancy can be effectively used to minimize downtime and ensure continuous operation. It involves analyzing the role of redundancy in supporting critical business functions and recovering from incidents, as well as considering the practical aspects of implementing redundant systems.

### 9.4.5. Remediation {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__remediation}
Remediation is focused on making sure that an incident can't happen again. Remediation may entail patches, firewall

changes, IoC database updates, or even adding more layers of security. The goal is to ensure that all assets are safe.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="9.4.6. Reporting"}


### 9.4.6. Reporting {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__reporting}
Reporting is a critical step. It is important to collect timestamped logs as well as accounts of how the incident plans

were rolled out. This can help you determine if the plans should be changed and can help you know what to look for in

the future. In the best case scenario good reporting lets you catch future precursors before they become incidents.

Disclosure is also an important aspect of the reporting phase. Both compliance and basic ethics mandate that customers

be made aware of any data lost. By disclosing the details of an incident you can also other companies aware of what

types of attacks are occurring \"in the wild.\"

:::

:::::::::::::::

## Case Study: Equifax
::: content

[In September of 2017, Equifax announced a data breach the exposed the personal information of 147 million

people.](https://www.ftc.gov/enforcement/cases-proceedings/refunds/equifax-data-breach-settlement){.link} The original

attack made use of an exploit in an outdated version of [Apache Struts](https://struts.apache.org/){.link} which was

being used as part of Equifax's system for handling credit disputes from customers. Once the attackers had gained access

to internal Equifax servers, the began gathering as much information as they could from internal databases.

What is particularly egregious about this data breach is that passwords in many databases were stored in plaintext. This

means that the attackers were able to try the passwords and usernames on other services. While it is important that

users use different passwords for different services it is far more disturbing that a company as large as Equifax did

not have the policies in place to use cryptography to mitigate the risks from such an enormous breach.

:::

</aside>

::::

::::::::: {.section .sect2 title="2.2. Terminology"}
topic: The lessons that can be learned from the Equifax data breach, including the importance of prioritizing security protocols and implementing robust measures to protect sensitive information.
question: What cryptographic technique could have been used to protect the passwords stored in Equifax's databases, and how would it have mitigated the risks associated with the breach?
answer: Hashing and salting.
explanation: The correct answer is hashing and salting, which is a cryptographic technique that protects passwords by transforming them into fixed-length strings of characters. This would have made it difficult for the attackers to obtain the original passwords, even if they had access to the databases.

## 6.4. EDR {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__edr}
Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) is used to secure endpoints: servers, workstations, desktops, mobile devices, etc.

EDR is typically implemented as a host-based incident prevention system (HBIPS), software that runs on the endpoint to

monitor and collect data.

These systems will usually watch for indicators of compromise, scan for malware, and can even quarantine or shutdown the

endpoint as needed. Company hardware is a significant investment for any business and an EDR makes sure that investment

is protected. Many systems exist for EDR including FireEye, SEP, and CrowdStrike.

:::

::: {.section .sect2 title="6.5. Data Loss Prevention"}
topic: The impact of EDR on preventing data breaches and protecting company investments in hardware.
question: How does the real-time threat detection and response capability of EDR solutions mitigate the risk of data breaches and contribute to the long-term protection of company hardware investments?
answer: By detecting and responding to threats in real-time, EDR solutions prevent data breaches and thereby protect company hardware from malicious activities that could compromise data or render hardware useless.
explanation: This question requires the domain expert to understand the functional capabilities of EDR solutions and their impact on preventing data breaches, as well as how this prevention strategy contributes to protecting company investments in hardware. The correct answer should reflect an understanding of EDR's role in detecting and responding to threats, thereby safeguarding both data and the hardware on which it resides.

## 6.5. Data Loss Prevention {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__data_loss_prevention}
Data loss prevention (DLP) solutions aim to stop the exfiltration of sensitive data. This could be personally

identifying information (PI), medical records, social security numbers (SSNs), credit card numbers, etc. Typically DLP

either functions on the endpoint and server, data at rest, or on the network, data in motion.

Network DLP solutions may monitor emails or web traffic for sensitive strings, such as SSNs. When an SSN is detecting in

an email, the email is quarantined and an alert is sent. Server and endpoint DLP solutions may periodically scan the

system to see if sensitive strings are stored on the system. If it is a system that shouldn't have access to sensitive

data an alert is sent. DLP on an endpoint may also limit tasks like USB usage or bulk data transmitting.

:::

::: {.section .sect2 title="6.6. IDS/IPS"}


## 6.6. IDS/IPS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__idsips}
Intrusion Detection Systems and Intrusion Prevention Systems are systems that monitor network traffic to detect/prevent

attacks. These systems may look for known exploits, such as SQL injection patterns, in the traffic and trigger an alert

when detected. An intrusion *prevention* system will take it one step further and actually shut down the connection or

kill the offending process.

These systems employ exploit signatures or IDs that are indicators of compromise (IoCs), anomalies, or strange

behaviors. The power of an IDS/IPS often comes from how up-to-date it's signature database is. There are many solutions

in the category including Splunk, QRadar, CrowdStrike, and SolarWinds.

:::

::: {.section .sect2 title="6.7. Email Solutions"}
topic: Network DLP solutions and their functionality in monitoring emails and web traffic for sensitive strings, such as social security numbers, and the actions taken when sensitive information is detected.
question: What specific action does a Network DLP solution typically take when it detects a social security number in an outgoing email, and how does this action contribute to preventing data exfiltration?
answer: Quarantines the email and sends an alert.
explanation: The correct answer reflects the understanding that Network DLP solutions are designed to prevent the exfiltration of sensitive data. When such a solution detects sensitive information like a social security number in an email, it takes specific actions to prevent the data from being sent out. This action is crucial for data security as it stops potential data breaches at the point of detection.

topic: Defining and distinguishing between key terms such as redundancy, failover, high availability, fault tolerance, and Single Point of Failure (SPOF) in the context of system security planning.
question: What is the primary distinction between fault tolerance and high availability in the context of system security planning, and how do these concepts intersect with the goal of minimizing Single Points of Failure?
answer: Fault tolerance focuses on survival despite failures, while high availability ensures consistent performance.
explanation: Fault tolerance and high availability are related but distinct concepts. Fault tolerance refers to a system's ability to continue operating despite a failure, whereas high availability ensures a high level of operational performance. The primary distinction lies in their focus: fault tolerance emphasizes survival, while high availability emphasizes performance. Minimizing Single Points of Failure is crucial for achieving both fault tolerance and high availability, as it ensures that no single failure can cause a system-wide outage.

context: ## 1.4. Threat Actors {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__threat_actors} To better be able to manage the risks of a data breach, it helps to be able to identify/understand the attacker or threat actor involved. Just as there are many reasons an actor may attempt to gain unauthorized access there are also many groups of threat actors. Neophytes making use of automated tools that they may not fully understand are often referred to a *script kiddies*. You may hear other pejorative names as well such as lamer, noob, or luser, but the common thread is that these threat actors are *not* highly sophisticated. The same techniques used for automating defensive security can also be applied to automating attacks. Unfortunately this means that you may encounter actors \"punching above their weight\" or using complex tools while having only a rudimentary understanding of what they do. Hacktivist are threat actors that attack to further social or political ends. These groups can be very sophisticated. The most well known hacktivist group is *Anonymous* which has been linked to several politically motivated attacks. Organized crime is another element which may employ or support threat actors typically to make money. These groups typically have access to more resources and contacts than a solo actor. It is important to note that threat actors with roots in organized crime may find it easier to migrate into other areas of crime due to their proximity to a large criminal enterprise. For example, while it may be difficult for a script kiddie to broker the sale of valuable data, a hacker working with an organized crime syndicate may have people close to them that are familiar with the sale of stolen goods. The last group of threat actors, and arguably the group with the most resources, are threat actors working with or for governments and nation states. These groups may have the explicit or implicit permission of their country to commit cyber crimes targeting other nations. Given the constant threat and resources available to these groups, they are referred to as an advanced persistent threat (APT). By utilizing the resources of a nation (often including its intelligence and military resources) APTs are a severe threat. ::: ::::: {.section .sect2 title="1.5. Security Plans"}

context: ### 7.3.9. Single Sign On (SSO) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__single_sign_on_sso} Given the ubiquitous nature of web applications, maintaining separate usernames and passwords can be difficult for users. A recent trend has been to support Single Sign On, where one identity provider is used to confirm that users are who they claim to be. There are a few protocols that make this possible, including SAML and OAuth. SAML stands for Security Assertion Markup Language and is an XML based Single Sign On solution. The SAML workflow centers around the SAML identity provider or IDP. The following steps take place to grant access to a resource via SAML: ::: {.ordered-list .arabic} 1. [User accesses a sevice]{.principal} 2. [User is redirected to SAML IDP with SAML request]{.principal} 3. [User logs in]{.principal} 4. [Credentials are verified]{.principal} 5. [SAML IDP sends credentials to the service]{.principal} ::: OpenID is another protocol that allows users to authenticated using a third-party identity provider in a similar fashion to SAML. One of the main differences is that OpenID was designed to be decentralized, allowing for multiple IDPs for users to choose from. In February 2014 OpenID introduced OpenID Connect (OIDC), a more modern system that allows IDPs to provide information about users via a REST API. This move was largely in response to the popularity of OAuth. OAuth is a method for allowing websites to access parts of a user's profile with the user's permission. OAuth is not *technically* a full-fledged authentication protocol, but it is often used as part of one. The following diagram highlights the differences between OpenID authentication and an OAuth flow: :::: ::::: {.section .sect3 title="7.3.10. Kerberos"}
topic: The comparison of OpenID authentication and OAuth flows, including their respective advantages and disadvantages.
question: What key advantage does OpenID Connect (OIDC) offer over traditional OpenID, and how does this impact the comparison with OAuth flows in terms of providing user information to services?
answer: A REST API-based approach for providing user information.
explanation: OpenID Connect (OIDC) provides a modern system for IDPs to offer information about users via a REST API, making it more flexible and widely adoptable than traditional OpenID. This difference significantly impacts the comparison with OAuth flows, as OIDC's REST API-based approach allows for more straightforward integration and user information exchange, whereas OAuth, although widely used for authentication, is primarily designed for authorization.

## 1.3. Hacker Culture {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__hacker_culture} The term *hacker* comes from the sound that programmers would make when typing or *hacking* away at keyboards. Originally a hacker was anyone who worked feverishly at a problem on a computer and the term *cracker* was used to define people who attempted to bypass security systems. The distinction was eventually lost and a hacker has come to be the popular term for someone attempting to gain unauthorized access to data. For an interesting glimpse into early hacker culture/reasoning read [The Conscience of a Hacker](https://archive.org/stream/The_Conscience_of_a_Hacker/hackersmanifesto.txt){.link} by The Mentor originally published in Phrack Magazine 1986.
## Hacker Hats :::: content An early attempt at classifying hackers involved assigning hat colors according to their motivations. This harkens back to the old western movies where the bad guys wore black hats and the good guys wore white hats. Just as in real life nothing is clearly black and white, as such we've laid the traditional roles on a two-axis continuum from malicious to benevolent and illegal to legal. ::: description-list [White Hat]{.term} : [These hackers are typically employed by a company to test the security of their systems. They operate legally with the intent of ultimately improving security.]{.principal} [Black Hat]{.term} : [These hackers operate outside the bounds of the law, and as such are subject to prosecution. Their intent is nefarious usually involving personal profit, malice, or some combination of the two.]{.principal} [Gray Hat]{.term} : [A gray hat hacker operates illegally but ultimately wants to improve the security of the system. They may inform administrators of the details of their breach or they may be acting to force a group to better secure their system. In rare circumstances a gray hat hacker may actually exploit a system for the purposes of hardening it once they have gained administrative access. It should be noted that despite the good intentions, gray hat hackers are still operating illegally and may be subject to prosecution.]{.principal} ::: There are several more hat distinctions (blue hats, green hats, etc.) with mixed meanings. For example a blue hat may refer to an external entity hired by a company to test the security of a component, as is the case in Microsoft, or it may refer to a hacker motivated by revenge. It is also worth nothing that the second quadrant of our graph is empty, but this does not mean that there aren't malicious, legal hackers. These may be software developers exploiting legal loopholes or possibly even individuals working for another government engaged in cyber warfare. ::::

## 6.1. False Positives / Negatives {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__false_positives_negatives}
When a security solution detects a threat, but no threat exists, that is a *false positive*. Depending on the complexity

of the solution it may utilize a set of rules, indicators of compromise, or possibly even artificial intelligence to

trigger its warning system. In the case of a solution that creates a lot of false positives, it can be tiring for a team

to go through each alert. Eventually teams are conditioned to ignore the alerts, making the security solution useless.

The key to lowering the false positive rate of a system is to better tune the rule set used to trigger the warnings. A

security team may spend time determining a baseline of events and looking for abnormalities that correspond to actual

attacks. This information can then be used to build a better detection system.

::::: example

::: example-title

Webroot Antivirus

:::

::: example-content

[In 2017 a popular antivirus service created a bad rule that identified certain Windows operating system files as

threats.](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/popular-antivirus-program-mistakenly-ids-windows-threat-creating-chaos-n750521){.link}

The antivirus solution quarantined these files, which were critical for the operation of the machine. The result was a

machine that was unusable.

For 13 minutes, Webroot distributed this rule to its antivirus software shutting down operations on an untold number of

machines. Fortunately Webroot was able to quickly identify the problem and send out an update which would have allowed

the machines to automatically fix the problem. Unfortunately their infrastructure for distributing the update quickly

became overloaded.

:::

:::::

When a security solution fails to identify a threat, this is known as a *false negative*. While no solution can ever be

100% effective, false negatives can undermine confidence in a product. False negatives may be resolved by a skilled SOC

team, closely monitoring what is happening. It is also possible to address false negatives through *Layered Security* a

concept that we will cover next.

::::::

::: {.section .sect2 title="6.2. Layered Security"}
topic: The importance of tuning the rule set used to trigger warnings in security solutions to lower the false positive rate.
question: What is the primary consequence of failing to tune the rule set used to trigger warnings in security solutions, and how can it ultimately impact the effectiveness of the security solution?
answer: Desensitization of the security team and decreased effectiveness of the security solution.
explanation: The primary consequence of failing to tune the rule set is a high false positive rate, which can lead to desensitization of the security team and ultimately render the security solution useless. This is because the team may become conditioned to ignore alerts, making it more likely that real threats will be overlooked.

### 9.4.6. Reporting {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__reporting}
Reporting is a critical step. It is important to collect timestamped logs as well as accounts of how the incident plans

Disclosure is also an important aspect of the reporting phase. Both compliance and basic ethics mandate that customers

be made aware of any data lost. By disclosing the details of an incident you can also other companies aware of what

types of attacks are occurring \"in the wild.\"

context: # 1. Introduction {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__introduction} ::: {.section .sect2 title="1.1. Managing Risk"} ## 1.1. Managing Risk {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__managing_risk} *Information security* (infosec) is largely the practice of preventing *unauthorized access* to data. Unauthorized access is when an actor gains access to data that they do not have the permissions to access. The system is often used in an unintended manner to provide such access. Data has become an increasingly valuable asset and the *risks* of others having access to data are incredibly high. Because of this, information security typically falls under the risk-management plan of a company and its importance cannot be understated. This is evidenced by the fact that information technology's (IT) typical role in a company has migrated from a basic service provider to directorships with a seat at the highest decision making table. This is directly due to the fact that IT assets have become the most valuable things many companies own. Guarding these assets and managing the inherent risk of their loss is the job of information security professionals. *Malicious software*, also referred to as malware, is often employed to help an attacker gain access to a system. Many types of malicious software exist, but the common thread is that they perform actions that cause harm to a computer system or network. In the case of many attacks, *system failure* may occur either as an intended (as is the case in Denial of Service (DoS) attacks) or unintended consequence. This means the system will no longer be able to perform its intended purpose. System failure is a serious risk that needs to be managed. ::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="1.2. Learning the Lingo"}

### 4.2.1. IP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ip}
IP stands for internet protocol and it was devised to allow creating a network of networks. The network of networks that

uses it primarily is the Internet, although you could use IP in other scenarios as well. IP is largely concerned with

*routing* traffic across and to networks. The protocol was first detailed by the IEEE in 1974 and comes from the

Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET) project, which created the first large, packet-switched network.

Most people are familiar with IP addresses, the unique number given to a host participating in an IP network. Currently

there are two main versions of the IP protocol, IPv4 and IPv6, and one of the major differences is in how many IP

addresses are available. IPv4 supports 32 bit addresses and IPv6 supports 128 bit addresses. To give an idea of how big

of a change that is, we have currently allocated all possible IPv4 addresses, but with IPv6 we could give an address to

every grain of sand on the beaches of earth and still not run out.

<aside class="sidebar titled" title="IPv6 Security Implications" epub:type="sidebar">

question: What significant advantage does IPv6 offer over IPv4 in terms of address allocation, and how might this impact the future scalability of the Internet?
answer: IPv6 offers a vastly larger address space.
explanation: The question requires the test-taker to understand the fundamental difference between IPv4 and IPv6, specifically in terms of address space. IPv6's larger address space (128 bits vs. IPv4's 32 bits) significantly increases the number of unique addresses available, thereby impacting the Internet's scalability and ability to support more devices.

context: ### 6.3.2. Proxy {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__proxy} A proxy typically sits between the users and an external network. Proxies and receive and send requests on behalf of a user, allowing for full control over the traffic going out and coming back in. Proxies can be used for caching, access control, URL filtering, content scanning, and even packet inspection. Proxy solutions may be explicit or transparent and are offered by many companies including McAfee, Fortigate, Netsparker, and Palo Alto. A typical application of a proxy would be to filter explicit content on a school district network. Proxies can also be broken into *forward* and *reverse* configurations. A forward proxy passes requests from a private or internal network to the internet. Forward proxies can speed up local requests through caching and validate that the request should be performed. Forward proxies are interoperable with standard firewalls and network address translation (NAT). Reverse proxies take requests from an external source and pass it to an internal service. This helps prevent clients from having direct access to internal services. Reverse proxies can utilize caching and validate requests as well. A reverse proxy can also be configured to work with a firewall. Whereas it used to be common practice to place a server in a demilitarized zone (DMZ) outside of a firewall, it is now far more common to employ a reverse proxy to reach that server. ::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.3. Load Balancer"}
topic: Utilizing proxies for caching, access control, URL filtering, content scanning, and packet inspection to improve network security and user experience.
question: What strategic considerations should guide the deployment of forward versus reverse proxies to optimize the balance between network security and performance in a large-scale enterprise environment?
answer: Consideration of internal network architecture, external traffic patterns, and security policy requirements.
explanation: This question requires the domain expert to weigh the advantages and limitations of forward and reverse proxies, considering factors such as caching, access control, and the potential impact on network latency and user experience. The correct answer demonstrates an understanding of proxy configurations and their implications for network security and performance.

topic: Comparing and contrasting MAC Spoofing/MAC Cloning and MAC Flooding in terms of attack vectors and network vulnerabilities.
question: What fundamental difference in exploit strategy distinguishes MAC Spoofing/MAC Cloning from MAC Flooding in terms of targeting network infrastructure vulnerabilities?
answer: Targeted impersonation versus table overflow.
explanation: This question requires the test-taker to understand the core mechanisms of both MAC Spoofing/MAC Cloning and MAC Flooding, and to identify the key difference in how they exploit network vulnerabilities. MAC Spoofing/MAC Cloning involves mimicking a legitimate MAC address to gain unauthorized access or launch further attacks, whereas MAC Flooding targets the switch's ability to manage MAC addresses, leading to potential network congestion or capture of sensitive traffic.

context: ### 7.3.9. Single Sign On (SSO) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__single_sign_on_sso} Given the ubiquitous nature of web applications, maintaining separate usernames and passwords can be difficult for users. A recent trend has been to support Single Sign On, where one identity provider is used to confirm that users are who they claim to be. There are a few protocols that make this possible, including SAML and OAuth. SAML stands for Security Assertion Markup Language and is an XML based Single Sign On solution. The SAML workflow centers around the SAML identity provider or IDP. The following steps take place to grant access to a resource via SAML: ::: {.ordered-list .arabic} 1. [User accesses a sevice]{.principal} 2. [User is redirected to SAML IDP with SAML request]{.principal} 3. [User logs in]{.principal} 4. [Credentials are verified]{.principal} 5. [SAML IDP sends credentials to the service]{.principal} ::: OpenID is another protocol that allows users to authenticated using a third-party identity provider in a similar fashion to SAML. One of the main differences is that OpenID was designed to be decentralized, allowing for multiple IDPs for users to choose from. In February 2014 OpenID introduced OpenID Connect (OIDC), a more modern system that allows IDPs to provide information about users via a REST API. This move was largely in response to the popularity of OAuth. OAuth is a method for allowing websites to access parts of a user's profile with the user's permission. OAuth is not *technically* a full-fledged authentication protocol, but it is often used as part of one. The following diagram highlights the differences between OpenID authentication and an OAuth flow: :::: ::::: {.section .sect3 title="7.3.10. Kerberos"}
topic: The differences between OpenID and OpenID Connect (OIDC) in terms of their approach to user authentication and identity provision.
question: What fundamental shift in approach to user identity provision and authentication does OpenID Connect (OIDC) introduce compared to its predecessor, OpenID, and how does this impact the security and usability of the authentication process?
answer: A more modern and standardized authentication approach using REST API.
explanation: OpenID Connect (OIDC) introduces a fundamental shift by providing a more modern and standardized approach to authentication, leveraging REST API for user information exchange, which enhances both security and usability compared to OpenID.

context: ## One-time Passwords ::: content To help mitigate replay attacks, an online banking application may require that client use a one-time password (OTP) when submitting transactions. An OTP is a frequently changing value that is known to both the client and the server. Several one-time password schemes exist, most of which make use of a cryptographic hash function with a shared seed between client and server. Periodically the client and server update to a new hash based on the seed and without the seed it is impossible to know what the next hash will be. By using an OTP anyone who intercepts the traffic will not be able to perform a replay attack as the password will not be current. ::: :::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="5.1.4. SSL Circumvention"} ### 5.1.4. SSL Circumvention {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ssl_circumvention} If you think about the intercepted key exchange given in the above MitM example, a similar attack can allow attackers to view SSL traffic. The attacker gives the victim a bogus certificate authority (CA) certificate which the victim installs. This is often accomplished via a trojan. Then the attacker places themselves in the middle of an uninitiated secure connection. During the key exchange the attacker creates a custom certificate signed by a bogus CA for the connection between attacker and victim. The attacker also makes an actual HTTPS connection to the service and proxies data for the victim. All of the victims data will show up in plaintext for the attacker but the connection will appear to be secure for the victim. This is used in the [Fiddler](https://www.telerik.com/fiddler){.link} debugging proxy to decrypt HTTPS traffic and is also used in some network appliances that perform deep packet inspection. Another MitM attack on SSL is simply to maintain or downgrade to an HTTP connection with the victim and proxy data to an actual HTTPS connection with the server. Most servers will upgrade an insecure connection, but by intercepting that exchange the attacker can continue to monitor the victim's traffic. ::: :::::::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="5.2. Network Layer Attacks"}
topic: The importance of verifying certificate authority certificates to prevent SSL circumvention and ensure the security of data transmitted over secure connections.
question: What is the primary consequence of failing to verify the authenticity of a certificate authority certificate in the context of secure web browsing, and how can this failure be exploited by an attacker to compromise data security?
answer: Exposure to man-in-the-middle attacks leading to data compromise.
explanation: The primary consequence of failing to verify the authenticity of a certificate authority certificate is that it allows an attacker to successfully execute a man-in-the-middle attack by presenting a bogus certificate that appears legitimate to the victim, thereby compromising the confidentiality and integrity of the data being transmitted.

context: ### 2.10.3. Elliptic-curve Cryptography (ECC) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__elliptic_curve_cryptography_ecc} ECC is an asymmetric encryption scheme that is quite fast and easy to computer. It is rapidly becoming the go to choice for digital signatures and key exchanges, gaining adopting starting in 2004. ECC is based on the geometry of a pre-determined set of curves (some examples can be found [here](http://www.secg.org/sec2-v2.pdf){.link}), which can be used to create a trapdoor function. ::: :::: {.section .sect3 title="2.10.4. Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange"} ### 2.10.4. Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__diffie_hellman_key_exchange} ::: float-group Given the slow nature of asymmetric algorithms, often an application such as a VPN will choose to use asymmetric cryptography to exchange a shared secret key and then use that secret key with a faster symmetric algorithm such as AES. Diffie-Hellman does exactly that and was first published in 1976. Diffie-Hellman key exchange uses the same mathematical concepts as RSA, exponentiation and modulus arithmetic, to great effect, but to visualize what is happening a metaphor of secret color mixing is used (see the included diagram). It is important to remember that because the medium of exchange may be slow a DH key exchange is designed to generate minimal traffic. ::: :::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="2.10.5. Digital Certificates"}
topic: The future directions and potential advancements in ECC and Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange, including their integration with emerging technologies and cryptographic standards.
question: How might the integration of ECC with quantum-resistant algorithms enhance the security and efficiency of key exchanges in future IoT networks?
answer: By leveraging quantum-resistant key agreement protocols based on ECC, such as those utilizing hash-based signatures or lattice-based cryptography, to provide long-term security against quantum attacks while maintaining efficient key exchange.
explanation: This question requires an understanding of ECC's current strengths and limitations, the potential threats posed by quantum computing to current cryptographic standards, and the need for secure and efficient key exchange protocols in emerging technologies like IoT. The answer should demonstrate knowledge of potential quantum-resistant algorithms and their compatibility with ECC, as well as the importance of balancing security with computational efficiency in resource-constrained IoT devices.

### 7.3.8. Sessions and Cookies {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__sessions_and_cookies}
HTTP sessions can also be used to control access to a resource. This is often employed in web applications. Upon

successful sign-in, a user is given a cookie with a cryptographically tamper-resistant session ID. Every request the

user makes to that site will include that cookie. Eventually the session will time out and the user will make a request

that is denied based on their session ID no longer being valid. Typically the website will redirect them from the

protected resource to a login page where they can log in again.

Website cookies may also be used to store user preferences or the current state of the application. A cookie could list

the items currently in a users shopping cart or specify whether or not the user prefers dark mode. Cookies have been a

target of scrutiny as they can be used in attacks. If cookies can be accessed by an outside application or by a separate

malicious tab in a web browser, then can be used to gain access to a users session.

:::

answer: Secure cookie protocols such as HTTPS-only cookies and the Secure and HttpOnly flags, combined with server-side session management and encryption.

context: ## 6.2. Layered Security {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__layered_security} Given that a single security solution is never 100% effective it makes sense to approach security in layers and use multiple systems. There is often a lot of overlap between solutions and while that may seem inefficient in other fields, in cybersecurity we consider it a benefit. By using multiple solutions, sometimes referred to as multi-layered security or defense in depth, you can build a more robust protection against breaches. Let's take a look at an example to see how layered security can help mitigate the effects of a real-world attack. Assume an SOC is supporting a web application on self-hosted machines. A malicious actor wishes to exfiltrate data from the web application. They begin by testing to see if SQL several different SQL injection attacks yield any results. A well designed web application should sanitize its inputs and may prevent the queries from making it to the database. Similarly an alert team may notice a sudden uptick in SQL queries, far beyond the usual baseline for the application. An IDS (Intrusion Detection System) may flag the queries as known SQL injection attacks. Assuming the attack makes it past the application, team, and the IDS, it is possible that the database user is configured according to the principle of least privilege and the queries will not be executed due to a lack of permissions. As you can see, any one of these layers may be fail, but by having multiple layers the chance of an attack occurring is greatly diminished. ::: :::::::: {.section .sect2 title="6.3. Network Solutions"}
topic: The role of security planning and strategy in implementing and maintaining a layered security approach.
question: What strategic considerations should guide the integration of disparate security controls to maximize the effectiveness of a layered security approach?
answer: Risk-based assessment and mitigation.
explanation: This question requires the test-taker to think critically about the role of security planning and strategy in implementing and maintaining a layered security approach. It demands an understanding of how different security measures can be prioritized and integrated to achieve optimal protection against breaches. The correct answer should reflect a deep understanding of the subject matter and the ability to apply general principles to specific scenarios.

### 3.5.2. SPAM {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__spam}
SPAM consists of large quantities of unsolicited emails. These emails may be malicious or they may simply be

advertising. In either case SPAM accounts for nearly 85% of all email. It is interesting to note that sometimes the

malware distributed through SPAM is actually used to send more SPAM through a victim's machine. The war on SPAM is

constantly evolving and while many updates have been made to the way we send email, many improvements have yet to be

realized.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.5.3. Dumpster Diving"}


### 3.5.3. Dumpster Diving {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__dumpster_diving}
Information that can ultimately lead to the spread of malware can also be found in improperly disposed trash. Old

records or hard drives may contain corporate secrets or credentials that give someone unauthorized access. It is

important to properly dispose of sensitive information, making sure that all things that need to be destroyed are

destroyed in a complete manner.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.5.4. Shoulder Surfing"}

## 9.2. SOC {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__soc}
A security operations center (SOC) is a dedicated team of security experts working within the business they are

protecting. Incident response and recovery is the job of the SOC. SOCs also set up preventative infrastructure, monitor

the environment, respond to possible threats, manage logs, and maintain compliance.

An important concept in the SOC is the idea of a *baseline*. A popular company may be attacked hundreds of times over

the course of a day. It is important that the SOC knows what the average volume of attack is so they can maintain

resources to respond. Through monitoring an SOC can establish a baseline of what is normal in the environment.

:::

context: # 1. Introduction {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__introduction} ::: {.section .sect2 title="1.1. Managing Risk"} ## 1.1. Managing Risk {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__managing_risk} *Information security* (infosec) is largely the practice of preventing *unauthorized access* to data. Unauthorized access is when an actor gains access to data that they do not have the permissions to access. The system is often used in an unintended manner to provide such access. Data has become an increasingly valuable asset and the *risks* of others having access to data are incredibly high. Because of this, information security typically falls under the risk-management plan of a company and its importance cannot be understated. This is evidenced by the fact that information technology's (IT) typical role in a company has migrated from a basic service provider to directorships with a seat at the highest decision making table. This is directly due to the fact that IT assets have become the most valuable things many companies own. Guarding these assets and managing the inherent risk of their loss is the job of information security professionals. *Malicious software*, also referred to as malware, is often employed to help an attacker gain access to a system. Many types of malicious software exist, but the common thread is that they perform actions that cause harm to a computer system or network. In the case of many attacks, *system failure* may occur either as an intended (as is the case in Denial of Service (DoS) attacks) or unintended consequence. This means the system will no longer be able to perform its intended purpose. System failure is a serious risk that needs to be managed. ::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="1.2. Learning the Lingo"}
topic: The different types of malicious software and their potential impact on computer systems and networks, and how to prevent or mitigate these threats.
question: What distinguishes a Trojan from a worm in terms of propagation and payload delivery, and how would a security professional mitigate the risks associated with each?
answer: Trojans require user interaction to propagate and can deliver a variety of payloads, whereas worms propagate autonomously; mitigation involves a combination of user education, secure coding practices, and network monitoring.
explanation: This question requires the test-taker to demonstrate a deep understanding of different malware types, their characteristics, and the strategies for mitigating their risks. It assesses the ability to analyze the propagation methods and payload delivery mechanisms of Trojans and worms, and to apply this knowledge to develop effective security measures.

### 3.6.1. Recon {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__recon}
Recon is short for reconnaissance, military parlance for a preliminary survey used to gain information. During the recon

phase, a malicious actor will gather as much information as possible. Methods used in this phase may be passive or

active.

Passive recon involves gathering information *without* sending anything to the target. This typically involves accessing

publicly available information, such as social media, published websites, and DNS records. If the actor has access they

may also passively sniff network packets.

Active recon involves interaction with the target. This can include port scanning, vulnerability scanning, [brute

forcing directories and filenames on an HTTP server](https://www.kali.org/tools/dirbuster/){.link}, or even contacting

workers. Active recon can yield more information, but it is also significantly easier to detect.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.2. Weaponization"}


### 3.6.2. Weaponization {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__weaponization}
In the weaponization phase the actor begins readying exploits for the vulnerabilities that were assessed during recon.

This may include tailoring malware, creating phishing emails, customizing tools, and preparing an environment for the

attack. For malware to be effective it must utilize the correct exploits and work under the correct OS and environment.

[Metasploit](https://www.metasploit.com/){.link} is a penetration testing framework that is often used in this step to

create custom malware.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.3. Delivery"}
topic: Analyzing the challenges of remaining undetected during the Recon phase and strategies for minimizing detection.
question: What tactics can malicious actors use to minimize their digital footprint during active recon, and how can these tactics be effectively mitigated by security measures?
answer: Implementing intrusion detection systems and regularly updating firewall rules.
explanation: This question requires the domain expert to think about the ways in which malicious actors can try to remain undetected during active recon and how security measures can counter these tactics. It requires an understanding of the active recon methods mentioned in the context, such as port scanning and vulnerability scanning, and the ability to think critically about how these methods can be detected and prevented.

context: ### 2.9.1. Block Cipher Modes of Operation {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__block_cipher_modes_of_operation} There are several ways you can create your cipher blocks and depending on how you do it, various attacks are possible: :::: {.section .sect4 title="Electronic Codebook (ECB)"} #### Electronic Codebook (ECB) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__electronic_codebook_ecb} ::: float-group The simplest mode of operation, data is divided into blocks and each block is encoded using a key. Since the blocks are encoded the same way, identical blocks will give identical ciphertexts. This makes it easier, given enough data, to determine what the key is. ::: :::: :::: {.section .sect4 title="Cipher block chaining (CBC)"} #### Cipher block chaining (CBC) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__cipher_block_chaining_cbc} ::: float-group Starting with an initialization vector (IV) each block is XORed with part of the ciphertext of the previous block to create a chain of ciphertext that is constantly changing. This means that identical blocks will result in *different* ciphertexts. This is the most common mode of operation, its weaknesses being that the algorithm cannot be run in parallel (sorry modern processors) and that the IV is a common attack target. ::: :::: :::: {.section .sect4 title="Counter (CTR)"}
topic: The impact of parallel processing on the performance of different block cipher modes, including Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) and Counter (CTR).
question: How does the inherent sequential dependency in Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) mode impact its scalability and performance in parallel processing environments compared to Counter (CTR) mode?
answer: CBC mode's performance is significantly limited by its sequential dependency, whereas CTR mode can scale better with parallel processing.
explanation: The question requires an understanding of how CBC's sequential nature, where each block's encryption depends on the previous block's ciphertext, limits its ability to be parallelized. In contrast, Counter mode can be parallelized more easily because each block can be encrypted independently using a counter value. This difference significantly affects the performance and scalability of these modes in environments that can leverage parallel processing.

### 4.4.10. DNSSEC {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__dnssec}
Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC) is a suite of extension specifications designed to authenticate

responses to domain name lookups. This can help prevent MitM attacks by checking the digital signature of the responding

server. While this is certainly helpful, it is important to note that DNSSEC does not provide confidentiality. DNS

resolutions can still be monitored by anyone who has access to the traffic.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.11. IMAP/POP3"}


### 4.4.11. IMAP/POP3 {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__imappop3}
Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) and Post Office Protocol 3 (POP3) are two protocols used to retrieve email from

a server. IMAP is the more recent protocol which supports saving mail on the sever and folders. POP3 is more primitive,

supporting only the retrieval (and subsequent deletion from the server) of emails. Both protocols use cleartext and are

now commonly run over TLS. POP3 defaults to TCP port 110 or 995 if using TLS. IMAP defaults to TCP port 143 or 993 if

using TLS. In the age of webmail it is easy to forget about these protocols, but a security specialist must keep them in

mind as they may still be used in support of corporate devices.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.12. SMTP"}
topic: Assessing the vulnerabilities of IMAP and POP3 to various types of cyber attacks and the measures to mitigate these risks.
question: What cryptographic protocol can be employed to protect IMAP and POP3 communications from eavesdropping and MitM attacks, and what is the primary port used for this secure communication in each protocol?
answer: TLS over ports 993 for IMAP and 995 for POP3.
explanation: The use of Transport Layer Security (TLS) is crucial for encrypting IMAP and POP3 communications, thereby protecting against eavesdropping and MitM attacks. The primary ports for secure IMAP and POP3 communications are 993 for IMAP and 995 for POP3 when using TLS.

### 4.4.9. DNS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__dns}
Domain Name System (DNS) is used to resolve domain names to IP addresses. Domain names are the simple names people are

accustomed to for websites, such as `njit.edu`{.literal} as opposed to `54.83.189.142`{.literal}. Names are

significantly easier for people to remember than IP addresses. In order for a computer to resolve a name, it first

queries a local cache, then its primary DNS server. Assuming the DNS server cannot find the name it will query a Root

server for a Top Level Domain (TLD) server, which maintains a listing of Authoritative Nameservers for that particular

domain (edu, com, net, org, gov, etc.). Finally once an authoritative nameserver is found it will respond with the IP

address for that particular hostname which will be cached and sent back through the user's primary DNS server to the

user.

DNS is designed to be resilient and decentralized but unfortunately the traffic is not authenticated or encrypted. This

has made it a target for MitM attacks. Likewise cache hits and misses [can yield information as to what names have been

recently resolved](https://kb.isc.org/docs/aa-00509){.link} (as was the case in discovering the extent of the Sony

Rootkit). The recursive nature has of DNS has also allowed for DoS attacks in the past, but much of that has been solved

by limiting recursive queries to the user-facing DNS servers (ie. the one given to you by your DHCP request). DNS

operates via UDP (and occasionally TCP) on port 53.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.10. DNSSEC"}
topic: The process of DNS resolution, including the role of local cache, primary DNS server, Root server, and Top Level Domain (TLD) server, and how it resolves domain names to IP addresses.
question: What is the primary reason why DNS queries are typically sent to a local cache before being forwarded to a primary DNS server, and how does this caching mechanism impact the overall security of the DNS resolution process?
answer: To reduce latency and overhead, but it also introduces security risks like cache poisoning.
explanation: The primary reason for sending DNS queries to a local cache is to reduce the latency and overhead associated with resolving domain names. However, this caching mechanism can also introduce security risks, such as cache poisoning attacks, which can compromise the integrity of the DNS resolution process.

### 2.10.7. Trusted Platform Module (TPM) / Hardware Security Module (HSM) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__trusted_platform_module_tpm_hardware_security_module_hsm}
These modules provide hardware specifically for use with encryption. HSMs are removable modules while TPMs are

motherboard chips. Many ciphers rely on a reliable source of entropy (randomness) which these modules provide. They can

also significantly increase the speed at which cryptographic algorithms run by moving the operations to specialized

hardware. Lastly, these modules can be used to store keys *and* make them only accessible via the module. This can add

an extra layer of security to prevent the keys from being easily copied.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="2.10.8. Steganography"}


### 2.10.8. Steganography {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__steganography}
Steganography is the process of hiding data in something such that to a casual observer it cannot be detected. Data can

be hidden in audio, images, or even [plain

text!](https://dl.packetstormsecurity.net/crypt/snow/description.html){.link}. The hidden data can also be encrypted if

an additional layer of security is required. In the field of security, malicious code may be hidden inside other files

using steganographic techniques. This makes it more difficult for tools to find them when searching storage.

:::

::::::::::::

topic: Evaluating the importance of encryption in computer systems security and how technologies like TPM/HSM contribute to this aspect.
question: How do Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs) and Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) mitigate key exposure risks in cryptographic operations, and what impact does this have on the overall security posture of a computer system?
answer: By securely storing keys and performing cryptographic operations in a trusted environment.
explanation: TPMs and HSMs securely store encryption keys and provide a trusted environment for cryptographic operations, significantly reducing the risk of key exposure. This is crucial because compromised keys can lead to the decryption of sensitive data, highlighting the importance of secure key management in encryption.

### 5.5.6. XML Injection {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__xml_injection}
XML stands for extensible markup language, and it is often used to transfer messages. XML can be an important part of a

web systems infrastructure and as such if unsanitized user inputs are allowed to generate XML the is used in the system

many things can go wrong. Using XML injection an attacker may be able to retrieve secret files or create admin accounts.

XML injection can be mitigated by input validation or possibly disabling the resolution of external entities in the

framework being used.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="5.5.7. LDAP Injection"}


### 5.5.7. LDAP Injection {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ldap_injection}
Finally, Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is often used to store information about users. As such, it can be

found behind many web applications. LDAP also supports complex queries in a similar fashion to SQL. An unsantized user

input can lead to a LDAP query with unexpected results.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="5.5.8. Directory Traversal"}
topic: Describing effective mitigation strategies for XML injection, including input validation and entity resolution disabling.
question: What specific configuration changes can be made to an XML parser to prevent the resolution of external entities and mitigate XML injection attacks?
answer: Disable external entity resolution.
explanation: Disabling the resolution of external entities in an XML parser can prevent an attacker from exploiting XML injection vulnerabilities to retrieve sensitive data or execute system-level commands. This can be achieved through specific configuration changes, such as setting the "expand entity references" option to false or using a parser that does not support external entities by default.

:::

</aside>

<aside class="admonition important deliverable" title="Important" epub:type="notice">

::: content

Come up with at least five different ways of getting free breakfasts and map them to real-world information security

:::

### 10.1.3. Container Orchestration Systems {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__container_orchestration_systems}
Containers also make it easier to restart or scale applications. Container orchestration systems leverage this by

monitoring containers and bringing them up or down as needed. The most popular container orchestration system is

[Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io/){.link}, developed by Google to manage web applications.

Given the orchestration systems create containers from images as needed, one of the obvious areas of concern is the

integrity of those images. If an image registry is compromised the orchestration system will still deploy the images

stored there typically making the issue far worse. Containers can also be hard to manage from a logging standpoint,

which may cause compliance issues. Whereas a company may have monitored the logs of a single server in the past, they

now have to monitor the logs of hundreds of containers running on a server.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.4. IaaS"}


### 10.1.4. IaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__iaas}
IaaS stands for infrastructure as a service and it refers to purchasing VMs or container resources from a provider. Some

popular IaaS companies are Amazon Web Systems, Microsoft Azure, and Linode. Each has some basic security tools and

default policies in place to help keep the purchased resources secure, but ultimately most of the security

responsibility for making sure the resources are secure lies with the group purchasing the resource.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.5. PaaS"}
topic: Analyzing the shared responsibility model of security in Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and the role of both the provider and the purchaser in ensuring the security of virtual machines or container resources.
question: What specific security controls and measures should a purchaser of IaaS resources implement to complement the basic security tools and default policies provided by the IaaS provider, ensuring a comprehensive security posture for their virtual machines or container resources?
answer: Implementing additional network segmentation, configuring robust access controls, regularly updating and patching resources, and deploying comprehensive monitoring and logging tools.
explanation: This question requires the domain expert to demonstrate a deep understanding of the shared responsibility model in IaaS security, recognizing the limitations of the provider's basic security tools and default policies. The correct answer must reflect knowledge of additional security controls and measures that purchasers can implement to enhance the security of their IaaS resources.
